<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><record_update table="x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases"> <x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases action="INSERT_OR_UPDATE"> <common_name>Brown patch (large patch or Rhizoctonia blight )</common_name> <description>How does the Brown Patch (Rhizoctonia solani) occur? Rhizoctonia solani reproduces through sclerotia, compact mycelium masses that serve as survival structures. These sclerotia persist in the soil or on plant debris. When conditions are favorable, sclerotia germinate, producing hyphae that infect plants. The fungus can also spread through spores, transported by wind, water, or equipment, facilitating the disease's dissemination to new areas.
</description> <family/> <host>zoysiagrass,</host> <number>PLD0001019</number> <scientific_name>Rhizoctonia solani</scientific_name> <solution>Treatment • Plant biofumigant crops such as mustards (Brassica juncea) in the affected area.
• Allow the plants to grow until they reach the flowering stage.
• Cover the soil with a plastic sheet or tarp to trap the released gases.
• Leave the cover in place for 2-4 weeks, allowing the breakdown of plant tissues to release bioactive compounds that suppress the pathogen.
</solution> <sys_class_name>x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases</sys_class_name> <sys_created_by>admin</sys_created_by> <sys_created_on>2024-10-21 23:05:50</sys_created_on> <sys_id>632d160f975112109790fefce053afa0</sys_id> <sys_mod_count>0</sys_mod_count> <sys_updated_by>admin</sys_updated_by> <sys_updated_on>2024-10-21 23:05:50</sys_updated_on> </x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases> </record_update>
